section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the letters Kk and Ll, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary (argues).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What things do the brothers argue about?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to compare and contrast.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach the letters Kk and Ll.
Read The Kitchen and The Little Lion.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What part of your body do you use when you listen to stories?
What do you use to smell what you make when you pretend you are cooking in the kitchen area?
What color are the counters? What do you use to see the color?
Draw something you would like to smell. Can you add a label?
What materials can you use to make something bumpy? Soft?
Look at the Alphabet Cards for Kk and Ll. Can you write each letter in the sand tray?
Can you build a long snake with blocks? Show me.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder focus attention, and introduce vocabulary (imagine, explains).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Close Your Eyes.
Read closely to notice and talk about when children are focusing their attention.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to compare and contrast.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Focus attention.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to identify which letter card is missing.
Encourage children to place the missing letter back where it belongs.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do you use your eyes to read a book?
Pretend you are making dinner for your friends. What would you make? How would it taste?
Show me something that feels smooth. Show me something that feels rough.
What is your favorite thing to taste? Draw a picture and write the word.
Can you make a tree? How can you make the bark look bumpy?
Can you write the letters Kk and Ll with finger paint?
Can you build a road? What do you hear when cars ride on it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Close Your Eyes by Victoria Pérez, illustrated by Claudia Ranucci. Text copyright © 2009 by Victoria Pérez. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Claudia Ranucci. Translation copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Thule Ediciones S.L. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to tap into prior knowledge and build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (listen).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Close Your Eyes and asking, Which boy do you think is right?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use pre-reading skills in self-selected books.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Focus attention (Self-Regulation).
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to self-select books.
Discuss with children how to hold and care for books.
Ask children to tell about the book they chose.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose a book. What do you see that makes you want to choose that book?
Pretend you are on the phone. What do you hear with your ears?
Connect some Connecting Cubes. Touch and count them.
Draw a picture of yourself reading a book.
You read about crickets singing in the night. Can you use these materials to make a cricket?
Make the letters Kk and Ll with finger paint. What words start with the letter Kk? What words start with the letter Ll? How does the paint feel?
Can you build a house with your eyes closed? What can you use to help you feel the blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Close Your Eyes by Victoria Pérez, illustrated by Claudia Ranucci. Text copyright © 2009 by Victoria Pérez. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Claudia Ranucci. Translation copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Thule Ediciones S.L.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch!

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the five senses, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (whispers).
Begin Story Time by connecting Close Your Eyes and See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch!
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: What can we learn from using our senses?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Relate own experiences to those in books.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Focus attention (Self-Regulation).
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Provide mystery boxes with items, such as a bell, cotton balls, cinnamon stick, and/or a picture, for children to discover using one sense at a time.
Discuss which sense was used to explore each item.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Close your eyes and listen to a story. How is it different from when you look at the pictures while you listen?
Create the tastiest meal ever.
Use Connecting Cubes to make three trains. Put them in order to show the short, shorter, and shortest trains.
Look out the classroom window. Can you draw and write about what you see?
Create something that feels good when you touch it.
Look at uppercase and lowercase Kk and Ll. How are they the same? Different?
Can you build three buildings? Can you put them in order to show tall, taller, and tallest?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Close Your Eyes by Victoria Pérez, illustrated by Claudia Ranucci. Text copyright © 2009 by Victoria Pérez. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Claudia Ranucci. Translation copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Thule Ediciones S.L.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children celebrate their senses by participating in scarf dancing and to introduce vocabulary (whispers).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How do our senses help us learn?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Respond appropriately to spoken language.
React to a variety of musical styles through movement and play.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Describe how you used all of your senses today.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Pretend you are the teacher and show and tell about a book.
Pretend you are a scientist. Can you use your senses to explore these buttons/rocks?
Find three things you would put in a mystery box that would be fun to touch.
Draw and write about one way in which you used your sense of hearing today.
Use the play clay to create a shape that’s interesting to look at and touch.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of kite? Can you draw a kite and write the letter k?
What kind of structure can you create with the blocks?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in prereading behaviors.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Respond to different musical styles through movement and play.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
